pires/android-obd-reader,closed,http method for upload should be POST,[Label(name=""improvement"")]","When I first used android-obd-reader I wrote a simple rest backend, wait for POSTs. From the settings and from my understanding of http methods this would have been ok. It turns out PUT requests are issued instead.
While it would be more backwards compatible to just change the settings description I think it would be wrong. From RFC 2616 [http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec9.html]:

> [...] The POST method is used to request that the origin server accept the entity enclosed in the request as a new subordinate of the resource identified by the Request-URI in the Request-Line. POST is designed to allow a uniform method to cover the following functions: [...]
> - Extending a database through an append operation.

> The PUT method requests that the enclosed entity be stored under the supplied Request-URI. If the Request-URI refers to an already existing resource, the enclosed entity SHOULD be considered as a modified version of the one residing on the origin server.
My interpretation: PUT updates an existing entity or creates a new entity with a known identity, while the POST is a generic ""here you have a new entity, handle it"" request.
In this case it is a new dataset, that has no identity, until the target server assigns one. So I'd vote to change OdbService to indicate a POST operation.

where RPM is engine speed in revolutions per minute, MAP (manifold absolute pressure) is measured in KPa, and IAT (intake air temperature) is measured in degrees Kelvin. This integrated value can be converted into total air flow (grams) using the following formula:

where R is 8.314 J/°K/mole and the average molecular mass of air is 28.97 g/mole. Note that in the above formula the volumetric efficiency of the engine is measured in percent and the displacement is in liters.

Once we have MAF integrated over time, we can calculate fuel flow using a specific air/fuel mixing ratio (A/F). A/F can range from 6 to 22. // This is a good place to enforce the imperial units option
// Now we can pass it along

When values are retrieved from an ObcCommand, it uses the getFormattedResult() method.  This method contains logic for printing either imperial or metric units, but depends on the invocation of the useImperialUnits(boolean) method to change this value; by default, it is false.  All commands that are created and issued are wrapped into ObdCommandJobs and dispatched using the queueJob(...) method in ObdGatewayService (inherited from AbstractGatewayService).  Since ObdGatewayService also has access to the SharedPreferences, it makes sense to make this change here.

An alternate solution would be to inject the preferences into the AbstractGatewayService and enforce the option to use imperial units in the existing implementation of queueJob(...), though that doesn't seem as neat from a design perspective.

happily sit and wait for it to be refilled again so we can just have one thread.

pires/android-obd-reader,closed,Fix #22 and refactor service binding code,[],The issue #22 probably was because the `onServiceDisconnected` won't be called when the client unbinds from the service (http://developer.android.com/guide/components/bound-services.html) but only when the service unbinds (unexpectedly) from the client. So even though we unbinded from the service, the isServiceBound was still true. This is fixed by doing `isServicBound = false` on the `doUnbindService` method.

Also, with this version, instead of binding the service at the `onStart` method, we bind (and start it) when the ""Start Live Data"" has been pressed. I believe that this is a better approach since the service is used _only_ when the Live Data is running so there is no need to bind to it when the Activity starts. After that, when we press ""Stop Live Data"" we stop and unbind the service.

pires/android-obd-reader,closed,Add MockOdbGatewayService,[],Extract non-OBD methods from `ObdGatewayService` to a common abstract class (`AbstractObdGatewayService`) and add a new service named `MockObdGatewayService` that will help us to debug the application.

You will see that the `ObdGatewayService` only implements `Start` (and connect to OBD), `Stop` and `executeQueue`. All other methods (create, bind, show notification, add job to queue, destroy) have been moved to the base class(`AbstractObdGatewayService`). The `MockObdGatewayService` will send the same bytes whenever a Command is executed there(`job.getCommand().run(new ByteArrayInputStream(""41 00 00 00>41 00 00 00>41 00 00 00>"".getBytes()), new ByteArrayOutputStream());` -- three commands because there are fake commands like fuel economy that are actually two commands).
I believe that the above is required in order to make debugging the application easier and help implementing new features (and testing the existing ones).

You will also see that the context is not injected in the `AbstractGatewayService` service anymore (was not working, probably because it is abstract ?). but instead is passed explicitly when the service is bound

Finally, the `executeQueue` method is started in a new `Thread` (and not on the UI thread) to lighten up the UI thread because there was a number of ""too much work"" messages -- this has the consequence that `stateUpdate` needs to be called through `runOnUiThread`.
